thread.title: Coast Guard veteran worked to help clean up 1989 Exxon Valdez oil spill in Alaska | Fort Cavazos Herald | kdhnews.com
thread.title_full: Coast Guard veteran worked to help clean up 1989 Exxon Valdez oil spill in Alaska | Fort Cavazos Herald | kdhnews.com

author: John Clark Herald correspondent
title: Coast Guard veteran worked to help clean up 1989 Exxon Valdez oil spill in Alaska | Fort Cavazos Herald | kdhnews.com
text:
COPPERAS COVE – John “Jack” Reed spent 20 years and 25 days as a physical oceanographer for the U.S. Coast Guard, and one of the major projects he worked on during that time was helping clean up the infamous 1989 Exxon Valdez supertanker oil spill that dumped 11 million gallons of crude into Alaska’s Prince William Sound.
Originally from Maryland, Reed was born in Baltimore and raised with two brothers on a 126-acre farm in nearby Millers that included 60 Black Angus cows and 1,200 chickens. He graduated as high school salutatorian in Parkton, Maryland, in 1969, during the height of the Vietnam war, and promptly headed off to the Coast Guard.
